oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Athenaeum Society, featured in the Yearbook “Salmagundi,” of the Boscobel College for Young Ladies, Nashville, Tennessee, 1907
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pictured: the members of the Athenaeum Society of Boscobel College, circa 1907. These are Mary Rust; Louesther Poston; Mary Bradley; Bernice Everett; Adella M’Cluer; Elizabeth Woodall; Vivienne White; Woodlie Sehon; Armour M’Cluer; Bessie M’Cluer; Isabella Washington; Inez Carter; Camille Webb; Florine Bond; Sydney Bilbrey; Reine Alexander; Lettitia Conner; Ruby Boyce; Lucille Forte; and Sallie Washington. The colors of the Athenaeum Society are Crimson and Gold; the Flower: Cosmos; and the “Motto--Hitch your wagon to a star.” The Officers of the club are Reine Alexander, President; Sydney Bilbrey, Vice-President; Lettitia Conner, Secretary; and Ruby Boyce, Treasurer. The Boscobel College for Young Ladies was a college in East Nashville, founded in 1889 as the Nashville Baptist Female College by the Tennessee Baptist Convention. The college operated for twenty-five years--until 1914. The campus was built around an East Nashville mansion, formerly owned by Anna Shelby Williams. The mansion stood atop a tree-covered hill overlooking the Cumberland River. The campus covered ten wooded acres on Sevier Street near South Seventh Street (then called Foster Street), south of Sylvan Street. In 1918, the property became home to the National Baptist Seminary and Missionary Training School, which functioned until 1931. The buildings were razed in 1940. Forms part of the yearbook collection: Boscobel College, “Salmagundi,” 1907. 1 volume
